Comment: I see the game being played:  >Yet while families have been squeezed by grocery sticker shock, agriculture corporations have been raking in record profits. Cal-Maine, the country’s largest egg producer, took in [$509 million](https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2025/04/08/egg-prices-profit-increase-cal-maine/) this quarter alone, tripling its profits from a year ago.  >Gouging consumers is bad enough. But it gets worse: Cal-Maine and other ag companies were breaking the bank at the same time they were also quietly getting [millions in taxpayer-funded relief payments](https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2025/04/08/egg-prices-profit-increase-cal-maine/) from the federal government. Congress and the Trump administration must put a stop to this: No company that is getting corporate subsidies should be allowed to hike prices and extract windfall profits from American consumers.  >Exorbitant egg prices have [ostensibly](https://www.nytimes.com/2025/02/25/business/egg-prices-bird-flu-producers.html) been caused by repeated avian flu outbreaks in recent years. Or at least that’s the industry’s story. As the advocacy organization Farm Action [explained](https://farmaction.us/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/Final_FarmAction_FTC_DOJ_EggPricesLetter.pdf) in a letter to the Federal Trade Commission, over the last two years, some 115 million egg-laying chickens have been culled in response to avian flu outbreaks — a tragically large loss of animal life, but a relative drop in the bucket in the grand scheme of the country’s poultry industry. Even after this reduction in the country’s chicken supply, monthly egg production only dipped about 4 percent.

Comment: We need to be blasting this on all channels. This is the sort of universal outrage that gets Dems and the Republican base fired up equally. I grew up around a lot of Indiana farmers. But because we Dems were so utterly absent from the area (growing up in Indiana sucked politically), there was no local Dem power to run on that dissatisfaction. Comment: People are angry at the wrong companies. Grocery store companies are price gouging y'all right now - not the egg producers.   Here's some stats: [FRED's avg egg price at the grocery store](https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/APU0000708111)  [Avg price for dozen eggs from producers in bulk](https://tradingeconomics.com/commodity/eggs-us)  H5N1 killed a ton of chickens, but cal-maine did a much better job protecting their chickens + recovering compared to it's competitors, and as a result are posting amazing earnings. Not saying CALM is a moral company though as they do keep the chickens in abhorrent conditions.   Notice how since March, egg producer prices have returned to 6 month ago levels but grocery stores prices have risen (probably going to hit 5.5 for April).  Grocery chains learned after COVID they don't need to lower prices after an increase.

Comment: it is confusing because u can get record profit during record inflation  easy example  item cost $1, your margins are 10%, you profit $0.10  inflation leads to item costing $1.10, your margins are still 10%, you profit $0.11  As a business you would report increased profit, but we also know that the value of those dollars are less cuz of inflation  im not saying reality is as simple as that, but when you see media headlines of equating record inflation with record profits, it can as simple as that but they can make it seem that its record price gouging, which requires further examination on a case by case basis

Comment: Egg laying hens are culled all the time. Hens get old and don't lay sellable or any eggs anymore, then they get culled.  The industry is mixing these two different reasons to cull hens to make things look grim. They also replenish with chicks at a slower pace now because they can raise prices to make more profits with less hens.   The industry also grows its own feed products, selling it to themselves at a higher price, but now needing less are able to sell that feed to other companies or countries for a multitude of animals.  You know what you don't hear? Manufacturers that use eggs complaining about the prices. They get their supply from dedicated farms, that don't seem to have an issue with getting eggs.  Mass scale farming and mass production have all their bases covered. They invest in each other.  Part of the club we can't join.

Author: RabidGuineaPig007

Comment: There was a short time in the early 1990s where adding applesauce as a "lot fat option" was mentioned in boxed cake mix instructions; since my mom was/is on a perpetual diet, she insisted we make one cake with the applesauce, just to try it. The apple taste was extremely overpowering and while I did like applesauce, and I liked cake, I DID NOT like applesauce cake. It would absolutely work if you were already making a predominantly apple-flavored dessert, but not for your regular boxed cake flavors such as chocolate or "yellow".  I didn't know until I read your comment that the applesauce was supposed to \*replace\* the eggs altogether. I now have a store-bought vegan egg replacement that replicates the texture very well, but still tastes a bit different than if you just used egg.

Comment: I only care when it comes to food (where it comes from).   Other goods could have parts from multiple sources. Frankly as a low income consumer. tariffs will put many things out of my price range. Simple things, like a new microwave. This has to be true for most low income consumers, which in turn will hurt companies profits as well as State revenue if they charge sales tax.
